importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the occurrence of the Houthi detention of UN employees in Sanaa, a significant escalation in the ongoing conflict over international humanitarian access in Yemen.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The incident occurred within a 24-hour period following a previous UN facility raid, indicating a pattern of escalating hostility toward UN operations by the Houthis.

keyTakeAways: Iranian-backed Houthi rebels detained 20 UN employees in Sanaa, including 5 Yemenis and 15 international staff.
The rebels confiscated all communication equipment from the facility, including phones, servers, and computers.
The detained employees belong to multiple UN agencies such as the World Food Program, UNICEF, and the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs.
The Houthis have launched a long-running crackdown on UN and international organizations in Sanaa, Hodeida, and Saada province, accusing them of espionage without evidence.
The UN has previously suspended operations in Saada province and relocated its top humanitarian coordinator to Aden due to prior detentions.
A World Food Program worker died in detention earlier in the year in Saada, highlighting the dangers faced by humanitarian staff.
The UN is actively contacting the Houthis and other parties to resolve the situation and restore control over its facilities in Sanaa.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Iranian-backed Houthi rebels in Yemen detained 20 United Nations employees, including 5 Yemenis and 15 international staff, in a facility in Sanaa’s Hada neighborhood. The rebels confiscated all communication equipment, including phones and servers, and have repeatedly accused UN staff of espionage, which the UN has denied. This incident follows a similar raid on another UN facility and part of a broader, sustained crackdown across Sanaa, Hodeida, and Saada province, where over 50 UN staff have been detained and one WFP worker died in detention earlier this year. The UN has suspended operations in Saada and relocated its top humanitarian coordinator to Aden. The organization is urgently working with the Houthis and other parties to resolve the crisis, restore control over facilities, and ensure the safety of humanitarian personnel.
title: Yemen’s Houthi rebels detain 20 UN employees and confiscate equipment
